meanings.definition: Squeeze or twist (something) forcefully in order to extract liquid.
meanings.sent1: She was wringing the wet cloth to remove excess water.
meanings.sent2: After washing the clothes, she began wringing them out before hanging them to dry.
meanings.sent3: He tried wringing the sponge, but it seemed to enjoy being soaked.
meanings.sent4: The chef's hands moved like lightning, wringing every last drop of juice from the lemon.
meanings.sent5: The old well had a rusty handle for wringing water from the bucket.

meanings.definition: Twist and compress (something) in order to force liquid out of it.
meanings.sent1: The wrestler was wringing his opponent's arm to make him submit.
meanings.sent2: She was wringing the wet towel to dry it faster.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick involved wringing a scarf to reveal a hidden object.
meanings.sent4: The storm clouds were like giant sponges, wringing rain onto the thirsty earth.
meanings.sent5: The old mop was not very effective at wringing out excess water.

meanings.definition: Obtain (something) from someone by force or pressure.
meanings.sent1: The bully was wringing money from the smaller kids at school.
meanings.sent2: The detective was wringing information from the suspect during the interrogation.
meanings.sent3: The salesman was skilled at wringing out extra discounts from hesitant customers.
meanings.sent4: The corrupt official was wringing bribes from unsuspecting citizens.
meanings.sent5: The negotiator was wringing concessions from the opposing party during the tense talks.
